name: Brainspotting (BSP)
summary: A focused therapy technique that identifies and processes traumatic memories by guiding attention to 'brainspots' — eye positions that correlate with unresolved emotional experiences.
description: Brainspotting (BSP), developed by Dr. David Grand in 2003, is a therapeutic approach that uses eye positions, or 'brainspots,' to access unprocessed trauma and emotional distress stored in the subcortical brain. The therapist helps the client identify relevant eye positions while simultaneously holding awareness of body sensations and emotions. By maintaining attention on these internal experiences, clients are able to process and release trauma more deeply than through talk therapy alone. BSP is rooted in somatic and neurobiological principles, overlapping with EMDR and mindfulness, and is used to treat PTSD, anxiety, depression, performance blocks, and other conditions.

contraindications: Severe psychosis or mania without stabilization
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Generally safe but can temporarily intensify distress during trauma processing.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Emerging — growing clinical support but limited large-scale RCTs compared to CBT or EMDR.
clinical_metadata.research_support: Studies and clinical reports suggest effectiveness for trauma and performance issues; more rigorous trials are needed.

sections.text: Brainspotting works on the principle that specific eye positions are linked to unprocessed traumatic memories and emotional states. By maintaining focus on a brainspot while simultaneously noticing body sensations and emotions, the client engages the subcortical brain regions responsible for trauma storage. This promotes deeper access to implicit memory networks and facilitates resolution of trauma without requiring explicit verbal recall.

sections.preparation: Therapist explains the process, ensures safety, and establishes grounding techniques.
procedure: Identify a target issue or emotional experience.
Guide the client to find an eye position (brainspot) associated with heightened body sensation or emotional activation.
Maintain focus on the brainspot while processing emotions and body sensations.
Therapist provides dual attunement — relational presence plus neurobiological regulation.
Allow natural resolution and integration of distressing material.
sections.duration: Short- to medium-term (may resolve in a few sessions for specific traumas; longer for complex trauma).
sections.total_treatment_time: Variable; 6–20 sessions typical depending on case.

items: Pointer or therapist’s finger (to guide eye position)

sections.pre_session: Grounding and identifying the target issue.
sections.treatment_phase: Locating brainspot, processing emotions and body sensations while maintaining focus.
sections.post_session: Integration, reflection, and grounding before session ends.

uncommon: Flashbacks or intrusive memories between sessions
rare: Dissociative responses if not properly contained

ideal_candidates: Individuals with PTSD or trauma symptoms
Clients seeking resolution of performance anxiety
People open to somatic and experiential therapy approaches
screening_required: Assessment of stability and support resources

practitioner: Licensed therapists trained in Brainspotting (Level 1–3 certification)

studies: Grand D. Brainspotting: The Revolutionary New Therapy for Rapid and Effective Change (2013).
Hildebrand A. Effectiveness of Brainspotting in the treatment of PTSD: A controlled outcome study (2017).
sections.limitations: Research base is smaller than EMDR or CBT; more large-scale trials are needed.

sections.insurance_coverage: Sometimes covered under trauma therapy or psychotherapy benefits
sections.cost_effectiveness: Moderate — may reduce long-term costs by efficiently resolving trauma

sections.children: Can be adapted with modifications and parental involvement.
sections.athletes: Used for performance anxiety and resilience training.
sections.artists: Enhances creativity by unblocking emotional barriers.

items: Relies heavily on therapist attunement and presence.
Does not require clients to verbalize trauma details explicitly.
Effective for clients who struggle with talk therapy approaches.
